text: Chest pain can be cardiac, respiratory, GI, or MSK. Always rule out acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with ECG and troponins.
Leg pain causes include deep vein thrombosis (DVT), muscle strain, neuropathy, or peripheral arterial disease. Assess for Homan's sign and risk factors.
Fever approach: complete history, travel, exposures, focused exam, and look for red flags like hypotension or altered mental status (AMS).
Hypertension management involves lifestyle modification (DASH diet, exercise) and pharmacotherapy (ACEi, ARBs, Thiazides, CCBs). Target BP varies by comorbidities.
DM2 initial treatment: metformin and lifestyle changes. Monitor HbA1c, fasting glucose, and watch for complications like retinopathy and neuropathy.
AKI is classified as pre-renal (volume depletion), intrinsic (ATN, AIN), or post-renal (obstruction). Check BUN/Cr ratio and fractional excretion of sodium (FENa).
Asthma exacerbation treatment: SABA (albuterol), systemic corticosteroids, and oxygen if SpO2 < 90%. Assess peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR).
treatment given: Albuterol MDI 2 puffs PRN or Nebulizer

text: Migraine abortive therapy: Triptans, NSAIDs, or CGRP antagonists. Prophylaxis includes beta-blockers, topiramate, or CGRP monoclonal antibodies.
Hypothyroidism treatment: Levothyroxine (T4 replacement). Dose adjusted based on TSH levels, typically aiming for TSH in the normal range.
Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP) coverage: macrolides or doxycycline, or fluoroquinolones for outpatients. Use CURB-65 for severity assessment.
AFib management: rate control (beta-blockers, CCBs), rhythm control, and stroke prophylaxis using the CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation.
treatment given: Diltiazem 30 mg PO QID for rate control

text: GERD treatment: PPIs (omeprazole) or H2 blockers (famotidine). Lifestyle changes include avoiding triggers and elevating the head of the bed.
Uncomplicated UTI treatment: trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim) or nitrofurantoin. Obtain urine culture before starting antibiotics for complicated cases.
treatment given: Bactrim DS PO BID for 3 days

text: Ischemic stroke acute management: IV thrombolysis (alteplase) if within 4.5 hours and no contraindications, or mechanical thrombectomy.
Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) treatment: SSRIs (e.g., escitalopram), CBT, and mindfulness. Benzodiazepines are used for acute short-term relief only.
Meningitis empiric treatment: vancomycin + a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) + dexamethasone. Lumbar puncture is diagnostic.
COPD management: LAMA (tiotropium), LABA (salmeterol), and inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) for severe disease. Smoking cessation is key.
Acute appendicitis diagnosis: clinical signs (RLQ pain, Rovsing's sign), elevated WBC count, confirmed by CT scan or ultrasound. Treatment is appendectomy.
RA treatment: Methotrexate is the cornerstone DMARD. Biologic agents (TNF inhibitors) are used for refractory disease. Focus on joint protection.
IDA management: oral ferrous sulfate, monitor reticulocyte count. Must investigate the cause of blood loss, especially GI tract in adults.
Hyperkalemia emergency treatment: membrane stabilization (calcium gluconate), shifting (insulin/glucose, albuterol), and elimination (kayexalate, dialysis).
Sepsis bundle: prompt fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour, vasopressors (norepinephrine) for persistent hypotension.
Cirrhosis complications include ascites (diuretics), encephalopathy (lactulose, rifaximin), and variceal bleeding (beta-blockers, banding).
Acute pancreatitis management: NPO, aggressive IV fluid hydration (lactated Ringer's), and pain control. Investigate etiology (gallstones, alcohol).
Glaucoma treatment aims to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) using prostaglandin analogs (latanoprost), beta-blockers, or laser/surgical procedures.
Herpes Zoster (Shingles) treatment: Acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir started within 72 hours of rash onset to reduce severity and risk of post-herpetic neuralgia.
treatment given: Valacyclovir 1 g PO TID x 7 days

text: Bipolar I treatment: mood stabilizers (lithium, valproate) and atypical antipsychotics. Avoid antidepressant monotherapy as it can trigger mania.
Active TB treatment: RIPE (Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol) for the initial phase. Monitor liver function for hepatotoxicity.
DVT diagnosis: Duplex ultrasound. Treatment: Anticoagulation (LMWH, DOACs) for at least 3 months. Risk factors: Virchow's triad.
treatment given: Rivaroxaban 15 mg PO BID for 3 weeks

text: Hypoglycemia (glucose < 70 mg/dL) treatment: 15-20g simple carbohydrates (e.g., glucose tablets). Severe cases: Glucagon or IV dextrose.
HFrEF standard therapy: ACEi/ARB/ARNI, beta-blocker, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA). Diuretics are for symptom relief.
PUD causes: H. pylori infection or NSAID use. Treatment involves PPIs and antibiotics (triple therapy) if H. pylori positive.
Hepatitis C treatment: Direct-Acting Antivirals (DAAs) achieve high cure rates (SVR). Screening is recommended for high-risk groups.
Osteoporosis management: Bisphosphonates (alendronate), Vitamin D, and calcium supplementation. Monitor bone density (DEXA scan).
Epilepsy treatment: Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) like levetiracetam or valproate. Drug choice depends on seizure type.
MS acute exacerbation treatment: high-dose IV corticosteroids. Disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) reduce relapse rate and progression.
Acute cholecystitis diagnosis: RUQ pain, fever, leukocytosis, positive Murphy's sign, confirmed by CT scan or ultrasound. Treatment is cholecystectomy.
SLE treatment: Hydroxychloroquine for all patients. Corticosteroids for flares. Immunosuppressants (mycophenolate) for organ involvement.
Tinea pedis treatment: topical antifungals (miconazole, clotrimazole). Keep feet dry; use antifungal powder in shoes.
Allergic rhinitis treatment: Intranasal corticosteroids (fluticasone), oral antihistamines, or leukotriene inhibitors (montelukast).
BPH treatment: Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin) for rapid symptom relief, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (finasteride) to reduce prostate size.
CKD management: Blood pressure control (<130/80), ACEi/ARB, glycemic control, and dietary protein restriction. Monitor GFR and albuminuria.
Acute diverticulitis treatment: usually outpatient antibiotics (ciprofloxacin + metronidazole) and bowel rest. Surgery for complicated cases.
CTS diagnosis: Phalen's sign, Tinel's sign, nerve conduction studies. Treatment: wrist splinting, corticosteroid injection, or surgical release.
Schizophrenia treatment: Second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, olanzapine). Psychoeducation and CBT are crucial adjuncts.
Acute gout treatment: NSAIDs (indomethacin), colchicine, or corticosteroids. Prophylaxis: allopurinol (xanthine oxidase inhibitor).
Viral gastroenteritis treatment: supportive care with oral rehydration solution (ORS). Avoid anti-motility agents unless infectious cause is ruled out.
Tension headache treatment: OTC analgesics (NSAIDs, acetaminophen). Prevention: stress reduction, biofeedback, or tricyclic antidepressants.
Cellulitis treatment: antibiotics covering skin flora (e.g., cephalexin or clindamycin, depending on MRSA risk). Elevate the affected limb.
STEMI acute management: MONA (Morphine, Oxygen, Nitroglycerin, Aspirin), P2Y12 inhibitor, and immediate percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
Hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease) treatment: antithyroid drugs (methimazole, PTU), radioactive iodine ablation, or surgery.
CA-MRSA skin infection treatment: Incision and drainage (I&D) for abscesses. Oral options: Clindamycin, Bactrim, or Doxycycline.
PID outpatient treatment: Ceftriaxone injection + Doxycycline + Metronidazole. Screen and treat for concurrent STIs.
Wet AMD treatment: intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF agents (ranibizumab, aflibercept). Dry AMD: high-dose vitamins (AREDS formulation).
TIA management: rapid workup to prevent stroke. Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor (DAPT) for high-risk patients. Carotid imaging is essential.
Acute otitis media (AOM) treatment: Amoxicillin is first line. Watchful waiting is an option for certain low-risk children.
IBS management: dietary changes (FODMAP restriction), fiber, antispasmodics (dicyclomine), or linaclotide for constipation-predominant IBS (IBS-C).
Rotator cuff tear treatment: physical therapy for partial tears; surgical repair for complete tears, especially in active patients.
Psoriasis treatment: topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs. Systemic agents (methotrexate, biologics) for severe disease.
Hypovolemic shock treatment: rapid infusion of IV crystalloids (normal saline or lactated Ringer's). Blood products for hemorrhagic shock.
treatment given: IV Normal Saline 1-2 Liters wide open

text: Syphilis treatment: Benzathine penicillin G, dose and duration depend on the stage (primary, secondary, latent, or tertiary).
treatment given: Benzathine Penicillin G 2.4 million units IM

text: Anaphylaxis emergency treatment: IM epinephrine (EpiPen) is first-line. Also administer H1/H2 blockers and corticosteroids.
Papillary thyroid carcinoma (most common) treatment: thyroidectomy, followed by radioactive iodine for high-risk patients. TSH suppression is key.
MDD first-line treatment: SSRIs or SNRIs, and psychotherapy (CBT, IPT). Assess for suicide risk immediately.
DKA management: aggressive IV fluids (NS), continuous IV regular insulin infusion, and electrolyte monitoring/replacement (especially potassium).
treatment given: Continuous IV Regular Insulin drip (0.1 U/kg/hr)

text: Acute bacterial prostatitis treatment: Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) or Bactrim for 4-6 weeks due to poor prostate penetration.
treatment given: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID for 4 weeks

text: Oral candidiasis treatment: topical antifungals (nystatin swish and swallow) or systemic fluconazole for immunocompromised patients.
treatment given: Nystatin suspension 5 mL swish and swallow QID

text: Pre-eclampsia management: delivery is the only cure. Magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. BP control (labetalol, hydralazine).
treatment given: Labetalol IV or Hydralazine IV for BP control

text: Parkinson's treatment: Levodopa/carbidopa (Sinemet) is the most effective. Dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors are other options.
UC treatment: 5-aminosalicylates (5-ASA) for mild-to-moderate disease. Corticosteroids for flares. Immunomodulators/biologics for severe disease.
Concussion management: physical and cognitive rest followed by a gradual, step-wise return to activity/play. Avoid symptom-provoking activities.
Asymptomatic gallstones require no treatment. Symptomatic cholelithiasis (biliary colic) is treated with elective cholecystectomy.
OSA first-line treatment: continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Lifestyle changes (weight loss, avoiding alcohol) are also important.
Otitis externa (Swimmer's Ear) treatment: topical antibiotic/steroid drops (e.g., Cipro/Dexamethasone). Keep the ear canal dry.
Infective endocarditis empiric treatment: vancomycin + gentamicin. Vegetations on valve are seen on echocardiogram (TEE is superior).
Fibromyalgia management: patient education, aerobic exercise, and medications (pregabalin, duloxetine, amitriptyline) to manage pain and sleep.
Varicella management: supportive care. Acyclovir may be used in adolescents/adults if started within 24 hours of rash onset.
Hyponatremia treatment depends on volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, hypervolemic). Correct slowly to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome.
treatment given: Slow correction with 3% Saline (for severe cases)

text: Breast cancer screening: mammography starting at age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines. Clinical breast exam is no longer routinely recommended.
PCOS treatment: lifestyle changes (weight loss), oral contraceptives (OCPs) for menstrual regulation, and metformin for insulin resistance.
The recombinant zoster vaccine (Shingrix) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults aged 50 and older (two doses).
Severe hypercalcemia treatment: aggressive IV fluid hydration (NS) and bisphosphonates (pamidronate). Look for underlying malignancy or hyperparathyroidism.
Atypical pneumonia (Mycoplasma, Chlamydia) is treated with macrolides (azithromycin) or doxycycline, as they lack a cell wall.
treatment given: Azithromycin 500 mg PO daily x 5 days

text: PN management: control underlying cause (e.g., diabetes), medications for pain (gabapentin, pregabalin), and physical therapy.
C. difficile infection treatment: Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin. Use contact isolation and hand hygiene with soap and water (not alcohol).
Inguinal hernia treatment: surgical repair (herniorrhaphy or hernioplasty). Watchful waiting may be appropriate for asymptomatic men.
Chronic venous insufficiency treatment: compression stockings, leg elevation, and exercise. Ablation or stripping may be needed for severe symptoms.
PMR treatment: low-dose oral corticosteroids (prednisone). Monitor for progression to giant cell arteritis (GCA).
Acute bronchitis is usually viral; antibiotics are not indicated unless bacterial pneumonia is suspected. Symptomatic treatment includes cough suppressants.
Acute seizure management: IV benzodiazepines (lorazepam, diazepam). Followed by a loading dose of an AED (e.g., phenytoin or levetiracetam).
PrEP regimen: Tenofovir/emtricitabine (Truvada or Descovy). Requires baseline HIV testing and regular follow-up for monitoring and testing.
PsA treatment: NSAIDs for mild symptoms. DMARDs (methotrexate) or biologics (TNF inhibitors) for active, progressive joint disease.
Kidney stone management: hydration, pain control (NSAIDs), and alpha-blockers (tamsulosin) to facilitate passage. Lithotripsy for larger stones.
Iron poisoning management: whole-bowel irrigation, chelation with deferoxamine, and supportive care for acidosis/shock.
Vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) treatment: aggressive pain management (opioids), IV hydration, and oxygen. Hydroxyurea for prophylaxis.
Rheumatic fever prevention: prompt treatment of Group A Strep pharyngitis with penicillin. Treatment: NSAIDs for arthritis, corticosteroids for carditis.
treatment given: Penicillin V PO for Strep Pharyngitis

text: Malaria treatment depends on species and resistance patterns (e.g., Artemether-lumefantrine, chloroquine). Prophylaxis for travelers is crucial.
Poliomyelitis vaccine schedule: series of four doses of the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) starting at 2 months of age.
DILI management: immediate cessation of the offending agent. Acetaminophen overdose antidote is N-acetylcysteine (NAC).
Delirium management: identify and treat the underlying cause (infection, drugs, metabolic). Use non-pharmacological interventions first; haloperidol if necessary.
treatment given: Identify/Treat Underlying Cause + Haloperidol 0.5 mg PO/IV

text: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral illness. Management is supportive: hydration, monitoring for warning signs (abdominal pain, bleeding, low platelets), and avoidance of NSAIDs.
Caused by Salmonella Typhi, spread via contaminated food/water. Treatment requires antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolones, azithromycin) and supportive care. Vaccination is key for prevention.
Endemic in many regions. Treatment depends on resistance; often Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) is used. Severe malaria needs IV artesunate.
Both are enteric (fecal-oral) spread, common in areas with poor sanitation. Management is primarily supportive; Hepatitis E is especially risky in pregnant women.
Multi-Drug Resistant TB requires specialized treatment regimens using second-line drugs (e.g., bedaquiline, linezolid) for longer durations, guided by drug sensitivity testing.
Leading cause of death in children under 5. Management: low osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) and Zinc supplementation.
Mosquito-borne viral disease causing severe, often long-lasting, joint pain (arthralgia). Treatment is symptomatic (NSAIDs) as there is no specific antiviral.
Vector-borne disease (sandfly). Endemic in parts of Bihar, Jharkhand, UP. Treatment: Liposomal Amphotericin B or Miltefosine.
Mosquito-borne viral encephalitis, common in endemic regions. Prevention via immunization is critical. Treatment is purely supportive.
Bacterial infection transmitted through water contaminated by animal urine. Presents as fever, headache, myalgia. Treatment: Penicillin or Doxycycline.
Caused by parasitic worms transmitted by mosquitoes, leading to lymphedema and elephantiasis. Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and mass drug administration programs.
100% fatal but 100% preventable. Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) includes wound washing, Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), and rabies vaccine series.
Highly contagious viral illness. Prevented by the MMR vaccine (two doses). Treatment is supportive, with Vitamin A supplementation recommended.
Often viral. Antibiotics are only used if bacterial cause or complication (pneumonia) is suspected. Look for fast breathing or chest indrawing.
Chronic infection requires monitoring and antiviral therapy (e.g., tenofovir) to prevent cirrhosis/HCC. Vaccination is routine for infants.
Common viral infection in children (Coxsackievirus). Causes rash on hands, feet, and mouth ulcers. Supportive care for fever and pain.
Preventable by DPT vaccine. Causes thick gray membrane in the throat. Treatment: Diphtheria antitoxin + antibiotics (erythromycin/penicillin).
Highly contagious bacterial infection. Preventable by DPT vaccine. Treatment: macrolides (azithromycin) to reduce contagiousness.
Bacterial zoonosis (from unpasteurized dairy). Causes undulating fever. Treatment: Doxycycline + Rifampicin for several weeks.
Caused by Clostridium tetani toxin. Preventable by DPT/TT vaccine. Treatment: Tetanus immune globulin (TIG), muscle relaxants, and wound debridement.
Consequence of untreated Group A Strep throat. Prevention: secondary prophylaxis with long-acting Benzathine Penicillin G.
treatment given: Benzathine Penicillin G 1.2 million units IM q 3-4 weeks

text: Highly prevalent, strongly linked to tobacco (chewing and smoking) and alcohol. Early detection via visual inspection is vital. Treatment: surgery, radiation, chemotherapy.
Preventable via HPV vaccination (for young girls/women) and screening (Pap smear, HPV testing) for early detection. Treatment: surgery, radiation, brachytherapy.
Incidence rising in urban India. Screening includes clinical breast exam and mammography (starting around age 40-50 for high-risk).

topic: ischemic heart disease (ihd) in young adults
text: Increasingly seen in younger Indian populations due to lifestyle changes, stress, and genetic predisposition. Aggressive risk factor control is crucial.
Defined by central obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance. Manage with diet, exercise, and targeted pharmacotherapy.
High burden due to smoking, biomass fuel exposure (indoor air pollution), and outdoor air pollution. Management: LABA/LAMA and inhaled steroids.
Often exacerbated by environmental factors like dust, pollen, and high levels of air pollution in cities. Stepwise therapy with ICS.
Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells. Requires lifelong exogenous insulin therapy and careful blood glucose monitoring.
Highly correlated with obesity and DM2 (Metabolic Syndrome). Treatment focuses on weight loss, exercise, and management of associated conditions.
Often alcohol-related or idiopathic. Management: enzyme supplementation (for malabsorption), pain control, and diabetes management.
Common complication of diabetes/smoking, causing claudication (leg pain). Management: exercise, antiplatelets (aspirin), and risk factor control.
treatment given: Aspirin 81 mg PO daily + Exercise program

text: High prevalence of genetic hemoglobinopathies in certain regions/communities. Requires specialized hematological care, blood transfusions, and chelation therapy.
End-stage renal disease is often secondary to uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension. Treatment: dialysis or kidney transplantation.
Most common form. Slow, asymptomatic vision loss. Screening is key, especially for diabetics and those with family history.
Leading cause of reversible blindness. Treatment is surgical removal and intraocular lens implantation, which is a high-volume procedure in India.
Simple vision problems (myopia, hyperopia) are a major cause of visual impairment, correctable with glasses. Public screening programs are vital.
Extremely common fungal skin infection, often recurrent due to humidity and poor hygiene. Treatment: topical or oral antifungals (terbinafine, fluconazole).
treatment given: Terbinafine cream topical daily x 4 weeks

text: Highly contagious skin mite infestation. Causes severe itching (worse at night). Treatment: topical permethrin for the patient and all close contacts.
Chronic bacterial infection, now curable with Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT). Early detection prevents nerve damage and disability.
Severe deficiency (Kwashiorkor/Marasmus) primarily affecting young children. Requires structured nutritional rehabilitation.
Extremely high prevalence due to low dietary intake, hookworm, and frequent pregnancies. Treated with iron and folic acid supplementation.
Major cause of preventable childhood blindness (Xerophthalmia). Prevented by Vitamin A supplementation programs and fortified foods.
Causes goiter and cretinism (mental retardation). Prevented globally by the use of iodized salt (Universal Salt Iodization).
Widespread, even in sunny climates, due to cultural practices (covering skin) and pollution. Treatment: high-dose Vitamin D supplementation.
Common, especially in pregnancy. Prevented by Folic Acid supplementation, crucial for preventing neural tube defects.
Contributes to growth failure and increases risk of diarrheal diseases in children. Zinc supplementation is routine in ORS therapy.
treatment given: Zinc Sulfate 20 mg PO daily for 10-14 days

text: Endemic in some states due to high fluoride content in groundwater, leading to dental and skeletal abnormalities. Mitigation via alternative water sources.
Caused by high arsenic levels in drinking water (e.g., West Bengal). Leads to skin lesions, internal cancers. Mitigation: filtered water sources.
treatment given: Filter water via activated alumina or reverse osmosis

text: Risk factor for low birth weight and neonatal mortality. Focus on antenatal care, balanced diet, and iron/folic acid supplementation.
Infection in the first month of life, a major killer of newborns. Empiric treatment typically includes Ampicillin + Gentamicin.
Associated with maternal malnutrition, anemia, and prematurity. Requires specialized neonatal care.
Major cause of maternal mortality. Management: Uterine massage, oxytocin, and prompt identification/treatment of source.
Seizures in a woman with pre-eclampsia. Requires Magnesium Sulfate (MgS04) for seizure control and delivery of the baby.
treatment given: Magnesium Sulfate 4g IV load, then maintenance infusion

text: Promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months and timely, adequate complementary feeding.
India is Polio-free, but continued surveillance and vaccination (IPV/OPV) are mandatory to maintain this status.
treatment given: Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) / IPV per schedule

text: Causes severe dehydration in infants. Preventable by the Rotavirus vaccine, now part of the national immunization program.
Bacterial cause of pneumonia, especially in children. Preventable by the Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV).
Screening and treatment (e.g., Gonorrhea, Chlamydia, Syphilis) are vital for public health and prevention of vertical transmission.
High prevalence. Caused by IDA, malnutrition, and worm infestation. Treatment: Iron supplementation and deworming.
treatment given: Iron syrup + Albendazole 400 mg PO single dose

text: Major cause of morbidity and mortality, especially in young males. Requires fast pre-hospital care and trauma center stabilization (ATLS).
Common issue in rural areas (accidental or suicidal). Management involves decontamination, antidote (if available), and supportive care.
Often related to musculoskeletal issues (back/knee) or neurological disease. Requires multidisciplinary management (physiotherapy, nerve blocks, pain medications).
Lack of awareness and social stigma prevents people from seeking help for common conditions like depression and GAD. Tele-counseling can help bridge the gap.
Growing problem. Treatment involves detoxification, counseling (CBT), and medication (e.g., naltrexone, buprenorphine).
Major risk factor for COPD and ARI, especially in women and children in rural homes. Promotion of clean cooking fuels is key.
treatment given: Adoption of LPG or electric cooking stoves

text: Common in industrial and urban settings. Prevention: hearing protection devices and regulatory noise limits.
treatment given: Ear Plugs or Earmuffs (in occupational settings)

text: Common during extreme summer months. Management: rapid cooling (ice packs, cooling blankets), hydration, and monitoring organ function.
treatment given: Rapid whole body immersion in cold water

text: Risk of Rabies. Post-exposure prophylaxis is mandatory.
While surgery is common, ensuring quality and minimizing post-operative endophthalmitis is critical.
Common in polluted, dry, or high-screen-use environments. Treatment: artificial tears, humidifiers, and lifestyle modification.
Often confused with asthma. Management: identifying and avoiding allergens, and symptomatic relief.
treatment given: Avoidance of known allergens (e.g., dust mites)

text: Regular screening (ultrasound, AFP) for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with chronic infection.
treatment given: Ultrasound and AFP blood test every 6 months

text: Lung disease that mimics TB but requires different antibiotic regimens, often environmental source.
Severe form of Dengue. Characterized by plasma leakage and shock. Requires meticulous fluid management in a high-dependency unit.
treatment given: Strict monitoring of IV fluid input/output

text: Extremely common due to poor posture, heavy lifting, or degenerative changes. Management: PT, core strengthening, NSAIDs, and weight management.
Diabetic nephropathy is the leading cause of CKD. Strict BP control (ACEi/ARB) and glycemic control are essential.
Staph aureus infections often requiring incision and drainage (I&D) and potentially antibiotics (if cellulitis or systemic signs).
Chemoprophylaxis (e.g., Doxycycline, Mefloquine) advised for non-immune travelers to endemic areas.
treatment given: Doxycycline 100 mg PO daily (starting 2 days prior to travel)

text: Common, especially in strict vegetarians/vegans and those with malabsorption (e.g., post-gastric surgery). Treatment: B12 injections or high-dose oral supplements.
A public health crisis. Requires judicious antibiotic use, infection control, and surveillance to guide empiric therapy.
Long-term exposure increases risk of CVD, stroke, lung cancer, and exacerbated asthma/COPD. Masks and air purifiers are protective measures.
Prevention through abstinence. Treatment includes nutritional support and management of cirrhosis complications.
Caused by inhalation of dust (silica, coal, asbestos) in occupational settings. Prevention: dust control and protective gear.
Public health strategy involving Mass Drug Administration (MDA) with DEC and albendazole to interrupt transmission.
Recommended for all adults over 30 (or earlier with risk factors) due to high prevalence. Screening tool: fasting plasma glucose or HbA1c.
Regular BP checks are crucial from early adulthood to detect and manage HTN early, preventing stroke/MI.
Clinical diagnosis based on cough, fever, and fast breathing/chest indrawing (WHO criteria).
treatment given: Amoxicillin (if non-severe pneumonia in outpatient setting)

text: Large-scale government programs distributing iron/folic acid tablets to pregnant women and children, often combined with deworming.
treatment given: Distribution of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets

text: Highly linked to chronic Hep B/C infection and cirrhosis. Surveillance via ultrasound/AFP is critical for early detection.
Time-sensitive care in India requires strengthening STEMI networks and rapid access to PCI/thrombolysis.
treatment given: Immediate transfer for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)

text: Approved vaccines are available but decisions on use depend on local epidemiology and seroprevalence.
Counselling, nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), or medications (bupropion, varenicline) are effective for all forms of tobacco use.
Integrated screening for DM, HTN, and common cancers at Primary Health Centres (PHCs).
Autoimmune (Hashimoto's/Graves') and iodine deficiency-related goiter are common. Screening with TSH is standard.
Extremely common. Management: high fiber diet, fluid intake, exercise, and bulk-forming laxatives (psyllium).
Lifelong Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) is the standard of care, preventing progression to AIDS and onward transmission.
Acute inflammatory episodes (Type 1/Type 2) require prompt treatment with corticosteroids or thalidomide to prevent nerve damage.
Persistent fever without clear cause, often requiring broad investigation for TB, Kala-azar, malignancy, or connective tissue diseases.
Adherence to the national schedule (BCG, OPV/IPV, Hep B, Penta, Measles/MR, Rota, PCV, DPT/TT) is the cornerstone of child health.
treatment given: Vaccination per Universal Immunization Program (UIP) schedule

text: djd
dejh
